Hi Ken. Thanks for adding this new feature. Now it is easier to 
analyze ge=
nome complexity vs. phenotype complexity. I know Picbreeder 
is generally i=
ntended to be a place for fun, but adding such features 
also helps researc=
hers to understand the workings of CPPNs. You know, 
it would be cool that =
a whole section for research purposes to exist. 
It may contain graphical v=
isualization of the CPPNs and that thing 
with the intermediate pictures at=
 each hidden node. And the God mode 
from DelphiNEAT's genetic art program,=
 too. Well it is only a 
suggestion, in general researchers can write their=
 own tools, but 
Picbreeder has already a huge database of interactively ev=
olved 
pictures, so it would be good to be able to use that. 

Peter

--- I=
n neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> I know =
some people have been interested in knowing the complexity of
> CPPNs that =
produce different patterns on Picbreeder.  To address 
this
> question, Pic=
breeder now displays the number of nodes and number of
> connections in eve=
ry published CPPN on the site.  The detailed 
display
> of any image (i.e. =
when you click on images that are in lists) shows
> information right above=
 the enlarged image.  
> 
> The most connections I've seen just browsing ar=
ound is around 500. 
> For example, "Habitable Earth" takes 477 connections=
 to represent: 
> http://picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=3D5776
> =

> However, some interesting images take a lot less.  The "butterfly,"
> fo=
r example, takes just 108: 
> http://picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?s=
id=3D4376
> 
> For those who don't know about Picbreeder, it's front page i=
s at
> http://picbreeder.org
> 
> ken
>
